title: Contributing to univariateML development
text: filing issue, important thing include minimal reproducible example can quickly verify problem, figure fix . three things need include make example reproducible: required packages, data, code. Packages loaded top script, ’s easy see ones example needs. Make sure potential data easily available us verify issue. Spend little bit time ensuring code easy others read: make sure ’ve used spaces variable names concise, informative use comments indicate problem lies best remove everything related problem. shorter code , easier understand. follow tidyverse style. can check actually made reproducible example starting fresh R session pasting script . (Unless ’ve specifically asked , please don’t include output sessionInfo().) miss particular estimator, make issue explaining implementation prioritized.

title: Contributing to univariateML development
text: contribute change univariateML, follow steps: Create branch git make changes. Push branch github issue pull request (PR). Discuss pull request. Iterate either accept PR decide ’s good fit univariateML. steps described detail . might feel overwhelming first time get set , gets easier practice. ’re familiar git github, please start reading http://r-pkgs..co.nz/git.html Pull requests evaluated seven point checklist: Motivation. pull request clearly concisely motivate need change. related changes. submit pull request, please check make sure haven’t accidentally included unrelated changes. make harder see exactly ’s changed, evaluate unexpected side effects. PR corresponds git branch, expect submit multiple changes make sure create multiple branches. multiple changes depend , start first one don’t submit others first one processed. Use tidyverse coding style. Please follow tidyverse style camel case allowed ml*** functions. Maintaining consistent style across whole code base makes much easier jump code. ’re modifying existing univariateML code doesn’t follow style guide, separate pull request fix style greatly appreciated. ’re adding new parameters new function, ’ll also need document roxygen. Make sure re-run devtools::document() code submitting. fixing bug adding new feature function, please add testthat unit test. wish provide new maximum likelihood estimator please read Implementing New Densities section . Make better algorithms maximum likelihood estimation can please prepared document superiority new implementation. seems like lot work don’t worry pull request isn’t perfect. ’s learning process members univariateML team hand help . pull request (“PR”) process, unless ’ve submitted past ’s unlikely pull request accepted . PRs require review approval least one member univariateML development team merge. Finally, remember univariateML -development package. honorably welcome pull requests contributions.

title: Copula Modeling
text: abalone data set included package. consists 99 physical measurements 41774177 sea snails. Following Ko, Hjort, Hobæk Haff (2019) take look four measurements abalones, namely diameter, height, shell_weight age. variable age present abalone data, defined age = rings + 1.5. Moreover, two outliers height data 1.131.13 0.520.52. remove outliers columns don’t need following.  Let’s continue step 1. First must decide set models try . Optionally, can use implemented models next step fit models, compute AIC, select best model. exactly model_select() . Now use fitCopula package copula transformed margins abalone. examine two elliptical copulas three Archimedean copulas. elliptical copulas Gaussian copula t-copula, Archimedean copulas Joe copula, Clayton copula, Gumbel copula. t-copula clear winner AIC competition. Archimedean copulas perform particularly poorly. Hence final model t-copula Kumaraswamy (mlkumar) marginal distribution diameter, normal marginal distribution height, Weibull marginal distribution shell_weight, log normal marginal distribution age.
code: library("univariateML") head(abalone) ##   sex length diameter height whole_weight shucked_weight viscera_weight ## 1   M  0.455    0.365  0.095       0.5140         0.2245         0.1010 ## 2   M  0.350    0.265  0.090       0.2255         0.0995         0.0485 ## 3   F  0.530    0.420  0.135       0.6770         0.2565         0.1415 ## 4   M  0.440    0.365  0.125       0.5160         0.2155         0.1140 ## 5   I  0.330    0.255  0.080       0.2050         0.0895         0.0395 ## 6   I  0.425    0.300  0.095       0.3515         0.1410         0.0775 ##   shell_weight rings ## 1        0.150    15 ## 2        0.070     7 ## 3        0.210     9 ## 4        0.155    10 ## 5        0.055     7 ## 6        0.120     8 data <- dplyr::filter(abalone, height < 0.5) data$age <- data$rings + 1.5 data <- data[c("diameter", "height", "shell_weight", "age")] hist(data$height, main = "Abalone height", xlab = "Height in mm") models <- c(   "gumbel", "laplace", "logis", "norm", "exp", "gamma",   "invgamma", "invgauss", "invweibull", "llogis", "lnorm",   "rayleigh", "weibull", "lgamma", "pareto", "beta", "kumar",   "logitnorm" ) length(models) ## [1] 18 univariateML_models ##  [1] "beta"       "betapr"     "cauchy"     "exp"        "gamma"      ##  [6] "ged"        "gumbel"     "invgamma"   "invgauss"   "invweibull" ## [11] "kumar"      "laplace"    "lgamma"     "llogis"     "lnorm"      ## [16] "logis"      "logitnorm"  "lomax"      "naka"       "norm"       ## [21] "pareto"     "pois"       "power"      "rayleigh"   "sged"       ## [26] "snorm"      "sstd"       "std"        "unif"       "weibull" margin_fits <- lapply(data, model_select, models = models, criterion = "aic") # Transform the marginals to the unit interval. y <- sapply(seq_along(data), function(j) pml(data[[j]], margin_fits[[j]]))  # The copulas described above. copulas <- list(   normal = copula::normalCopula(dim = 4, dispstr = "un"),   t = copula::tCopula(dim = 4, dispstr = "un"),   joe = copula::joeCopula(dim = 4),   clayton = copula::claytonCopula(dim = 4),   gumbel = copula::gumbelCopula(dim = 4) )  fits <- sapply(   copulas,   function(x) copula::fitCopula(x, data = y, method = "mpl") )  sapply(fits, AIC) ##     normal          t        joe    clayton     gumbel  ## -21822.309 -23152.657  -8668.457 -16502.422 -12821.817

title: Distributions
text: maximum likelihood estimator Lomax distribution frequently fails exist. assume κ→λ−1x¯−1\kappa\\lambda^{-1}\overline{x}^{-1} λ→0\lambda\to0. density λκ(1+λx)−(κ+1)\lambda\kappa\left(1+\lambda x\right)^{-\left(\kappa+1\right)} approximately equal λκ(1+λx)−(λ−1x¯−1+1)\lambda\kappa\left(1+\lambda x\right)^{-\left(\lambda^{-1}\overline{x}^{-1}+1\right)} λ\lambda small enough. Since λκ(1+λx)−(λ−1x¯−1+1)→x¯−1e−x¯−1x\lambda\kappa\left(1+\lambda x\right)^{-\left(\lambda^{-1}\overline{x}^{-1}+1\right)}\\overline{x}^{-1}e^{-\overline{x}^{-1}x}, density converges exponential density.
code: eps <- 0.1 x <- seq(0, 3, length.out = 100) plot(dexp, 0, 3, xlab = "x", ylab = "Density", main = "Exponential and Lomax") lines(x, extraDistr::dlomax(x, lambda = eps, kappa = 1 / eps), col = "red")

title: Overview of univariateML
text: dataset egypt contains contains age death 141 Roman era Egyptian mummies. first task find univariate model fits data.
code: library("univariateML") head(egypt) ##    age  sex ## 1 1.50 male ## 2 1.83 male ## 3 2.00 male ## 4 2.00 male ## 5 3.00 male ## 6 3.00 male hist(egypt$age, main = "Mortality in Ancient Egypt", freq = FALSE)

title: Overview of univariateML
text: AIC handy easy use model selection tool, depends log-likelihood number parameters models. generic R can take multiple models, lower better. Since data positive try densities support positive half-line. Weibull Gamma models stand AIC far candidate models. see parameter estimates mlweibull(egypt$age) just print : mlweibull(egypt$age) univariateML object. details call summary:
code: AIC(   mlbetapr(egypt$age),   mlexp(egypt$age),   mlinvgamma(egypt$age),   mlgamma(egypt$age),   mllnorm(egypt$age),   mlrayleigh(egypt$age),   mlinvgauss(egypt$age),   mlweibull(egypt$age),   mlinvweibull(egypt$age),   mllgamma(egypt$age) ) ##                         df      AIC ## mlbetapr(egypt$age)      2 1312.464 ## mlexp(egypt$age)         1 1249.553 ## mlinvgamma(egypt$age)    2 1322.949 ## mlgamma(egypt$age)       2 1234.772 ## mllnorm(egypt$age)       2 1263.874 ## mlrayleigh(egypt$age)    1 1260.217 ## mlinvgauss(egypt$age)    2 1287.124 ## mlweibull(egypt$age)     2 1230.229 ## mlinvweibull(egypt$age)  2 1319.120 ## mllgamma(egypt$age)      2 1314.187 mlweibull(egypt$age) ## Maximum likelihood estimates for the Weibull model  ##  shape   scale   ##  1.404  33.564 summary(mlweibull(egypt$age)) ##  ## Maximum likelihood for the Weibull model  ##   ## Call:  mlweibull(x = egypt$age)  ##  ## Estimates:  ##     shape      scale   ##  1.404158  33.563564   ##  ## Data:            egypt$age (141 obs.) ## Support:         (0, Inf) ## Density:         stats::dweibull ## Log-likelihood:  -613.1144

title: Overview of univariateML
text: Now investigate two models differ quantile-quantile plots, Q-Q plots short.  Q-Q plot shows neither Weibull Gamma fits data well. prefer P-P plots Q-Q plots take look ?ppplotml instead.
code: qqmlplot(egypt$age, mlweibull, datax = TRUE, main = "QQ Plot for Ancient Egypt") # Can also use qqmlplot(mlweibull(egypt$age), datax = TRUE) directly. qqmlpoints(egypt$age, mlgamma, datax = TRUE, col = "red") qqmlline(egypt$age, mlweibull, datax = TRUE) qqmlline(egypt$age, mlgamma, datax = TRUE, col = "red")

title: Overview of univariateML
text: Use plot, lines points generics plot densities.
code: hist(egypt$age, main = "Mortality in Ancient Egypt", freq = FALSE) lines(mlweibull(egypt$age), lwd = 2, lty = 2, ylim = c(0, 0.025)) lines(mlgamma(egypt$age), lwd = 2, col = "red") rug(egypt$age)

title: Overview of univariateML
text: Now want get idea uncertainties model parameters. can parametric bootstrap calculate confidence intervals using either bootstrapml confint. bootstrapml allows calculate functional parameters manipulate afterwards, confint restricted main parameters model. confidence intervals directly comparable. , scale parameter Weibull model directly comparable rate parameter gamma model. let us take look parameter familiar interpretation, namely mean. mean Weibull distribution parameters shape scale scale*gamma(1 + 1/shape). hand, mean Gamma distribution parameters shape rate shape/rate. probs argument can used modify limits confidence interval. Now calculate two 90% confidence intervals mean. interested quantiles underlying distribution, instance median: can also plot bootstrap samples.
code: # Calculate two-sided 95% confidence intervals for the two Gumbel parameters. bootstrapml(mlweibull(egypt$age)) # same as confint(mlweibull(egypt$age)) ##            2.5%     97.5% ## shape  1.254423  1.605348 ## scale 29.508024 37.593804 bootstrapml(mlgamma(egypt$age)) ##             2.5%      97.5% ## shape 1.33060626 2.03281196 ## rate  0.04151886 0.06912931 # Calculate two-sided 90% confidence intervals for the mean of a Weibull. bootstrapml(mlweibull(egypt$age),   map = function(x) x[2] * gamma(1 + 1 / x[1]),   probs = c(0.05, 0.95) ) ##       5%      95%  ## 27.51011 33.73273 # Calculate two-sided 90% confidence intervals for the mean of a Gamma. bootstrapml(mlgamma(egypt$age),   map = function(x) x[1] / x[2],   probs = c(0.05, 0.95) ) ##       5%      95%  ## 27.53893 34.11073 # Calculate two-sided 90% confidence intervals for the two Gumbel parameters. bootstrapml(mlweibull(egypt$age),   map = function(x) qweibull(0.5, x[1], x[2]),   probs = c(0.05, 0.95) ) ##       5%      95%  ## 22.94823 28.81159 bootstrapml(mlgamma(egypt$age),   map = function(x) qgamma(0.5, x[1], x[2]),   probs = c(0.05, 0.95) ) ##       5%      95%  ## 21.95519 27.63972 hist(   bootstrapml(mlweibull(egypt$age),     map = function(x) x[2] * gamma(1 + 1 / x[1]),     reducer = identity   ),   main = "Bootstrap Samples of the Mean",   xlab = "x",   freq = FALSE )

what: Density, CDF, quantiles and random variate generation
title: Overview of univariateML
text: functions dml, pml, qml rml can used calculate densities, cumulative probabilities, quantiles, generate random variables. 1010 random observations likely distribution Egyptian mortalities given Weibull model. Compare empirical distribution random variates true cumulative probability.
code: set.seed(313) rml(10, mlweibull(egypt$age)) ##  [1] 25.90552 59.64456 13.36882 44.29378 12.22563 17.66144 54.57633 22.86824 ##  [9] 11.48328 19.94814 set.seed(313) obj <- mlweibull(egypt$age) q <- seq(0, max(egypt$age), length.out = 100) plot(q, pml(q, obj), type = "l", ylab = "Cumulative Probability") r <- rml(100, obj) lines(ecdf(r))

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Univariate Densities

code: library("univariateML") mlweibull(egypt$age) #> Maximum likelihood estimates for the Weibull model  #>  shape   scale   #>  1.404  33.564 hist(egypt$age, freq = FALSE, xlab = "Mortality", main = "Egypt") lines(mlweibull(egypt$age))

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Univariate Densities
text: Analytic formulae maximum likelihood estimates used whenever exist. ml*** functions without analytic solutions custom made Newton-Raphson solver. can much faster naïve solution using nlm optim. example, mlbeta large speedup naïve solution using nlm. maximum likelihood estimators package subject testing, see tests folder details.
code: # install.packages("microbenchmark") set.seed(313) x <- rbeta(500, 2, 7)  microbenchmark::microbenchmark(   univariateML = univariateML::mlbeta(x),   naive = nlm(function(p) -sum(dbeta(x, p[1], p[2], log = TRUE)), p = c(1, 1)) ) #> Unit: microseconds #>          expr     min       lq      mean   median       uq      max neval #>  univariateML   205.1   329.85   800.077   464.35   730.35  13938.4   100 #>         naive 10665.9 11773.30 21428.104 15233.70 28628.65 103372.1   100

code: # \donttest{ set.seed(1) object <- mlgamma(mtcars$qsec)  ## Calculate c(0.025, 0.975) confidence interval for the gamma parameters. bootstrapml(object) #>            2.5%     97.5% #> shape 70.285697 180.72290 #> rate   3.965363  10.12785  #            2.5%      97.5% # shape 68.624945 160.841557 # rate   3.896915   9.089194  ## The mean of a gamma distribution is shape/rate. Now we calculate a ## parametric bootstrap confidence interval for the mean with confidence ## limits c(0.05, 0.95)  bootstrapml(object, map = function(x) x[1] / x[2], probs = c(0.05, 0.95)) #>       5%      95%  #> 17.33962 18.31253   #       5%      95% # 17.33962 18.31253  ## Print a histogram of the bootstrapped estimates from an exponential. object <- mlexp(mtcars$qsec) hist(bootstrapml(object, reducer = identity))  # }
